Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Personalizing Recommendations in a Large-scale Education Analytics Pipeline

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This pilot project aims to begin to organize the world's digital learning resources to make personalized recommendations to learners that are engaging and effective in increasing mathematics learning outcomes. The project accomplishes this goal by developing crowdsourcing techniques to organize learning resources and by analyzing the online learning activities of the student. Teachers are an integral part of this project. The target audience for this pilot is 7th grade mathematics students and teachers.

This project builds upon the Gooru platform that serves a community of over 500,000 in 140 countries and all 50 US states. The platform uses crowdsourcing by its community to curate over 70,000 collections of free web resources consisting of over 16,000,000 education resources. This project builds upon the Gooru resources by using learning analytics on the user interactions within Gooru to discover the resources that most benefit students. Thus, student resources can be tailored to the individual student to maximally engage the student and improve the students learning. Since the Gooru user owns his or her data, explicit opt-in is required for the sharing of data thus protecting the privacy of students who wish not to share their data. Gooru is open source and free so there are no economic barriers (besides internet access) to using the platform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research supported by this grant significantly advanced the state of AI in higher education, pushing beyond predictive modeling to design and deploy human-centered interventions driven by nascent neural recommender algorithms in a variety of educational contexts. 

The work of the grant produced the first demonstration of a deployed adaptive recommendation algorithm in a massive open online course (Fig. 1). The algorithm, utilizing a session-based recurrent neural network, modeled the click behavior of students in past offerings of the course to produce a just-in-time next-step recommendation at the bottom of each page (Fig. 2) based on a prediction of which resource the learner was likely to spend significant time on next. The paper [1], which describes the algorithm adaptation and novel engineering augmentation of the edX platform, was one of four papers featured in the edX 2020 Impact Report, summarizing the most significant findings involving edX since their inception in 2012.

Instructors of online courses can lose a sense for learner engagement. In [2], an instructor dashboard and communication interface was designed (Fig. 3) to allow instructors to see predictive analytics about learner engagement and tailor messages to groups of learners conditioned on these analytics (e.g., sending a message to learners who were currently predicted to finish the course but not pass). The interface, called the "Communicator," was piloted in a live course and integrated into the edX platform codebase. 

The research of the grant achieved another first, this time in the context of formal degree-seeking higher education, with the first university-wide study of enrollment data from a machine learning perspective and real-world deployment of an AI-based course recommender system (Fig. 4). The system began with a similar recurrent neural network approach as in the online course scenario, with a collaborative filtering-style next-course recommender with an additional exploration feature that returned the nearest neighbor courses to a course specified by a student [3]. This course similarity feature utilized a vector space of courses learned from enrollment sequences.

Recognizing that the values of a liberal arts university include students plotting their own path and broadening their perspectives, a goal-based algorithm was designed whereby a student could specify a goal course and grade and receive suggested preparatory courses tailored to them based on their course and grade history [4]. While many courses already list prerequisites, these are not comprehensive and are not personalized based on what each individual student has already covered. The algorithm was based on a type of counterfactual inference that was later improved to have backpropagation fit the possible inputs that would maximize the target course and grade objective [5].

Finally, to facilitate student discovery of new courses, the project focused on optimizing student perceptions of surprise or unexpectedness while keeping recommendations relevant. Achieving this balance is called serendipity. A user study of 70 students was run where different algorithms were trialed [6]. The results suggested that explanations may need to be generated for users in order to justify the recommendations of the more complex algorithms, which utilized a variety of data sources to inform their course representations. 

The research of [3-6] was conducted on and contributed to a fielded system at UC Berkeley called AskOski, used by over 10,000 students per year.

[1] Pardos, Z. A., Tang, S., Davis, D., Le. C.V. (2017) Enabling Real-Time Adaptivity in MOOCs with a Personalized Next-Step Recommendation Framework. In C. Thille & J. Reich (Eds.) Proceedings of the 4th Conference on Learning @ Scale (L@S). ACM. Pages 23-32. [code]

[2] Le, C.V., Pardos, Z. A., Meyer, S.D., Thorp, R. (2018) Communication at Scale in a MOOC Using Predictive Engagement Analytics. In M. Mavrikis, K. Porayska-Pomsta & R. Luckin (Eds.) Proceedings of the 19th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED). London, UK. Pages 239-252. [code]

[3] Pardos, Z.A., Fan, Z., Jiang, W. (2019) Connectionist Recommendation in the Wild: On the utility and scrutability of neural networks for personalized course guidance. User Modeling and User-Adapted Interaction, 29(2), 487?525.

[4] Jiang, W., Pardos, Z. A., Wei, Q. (2019) Goal-based Course Recommendation. In C. Brooks, R. Ferguson & U. Hoppe (Eds.) Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK). ACM. Tempe, Arizona. Pages 36-45. [code]

[5] Jiang, W., Pardos, Z.A. (2019) Time Slice Imputation for Personalized Goal-based Recommendation in Higher Education. In D. Tikk & P. Brusilovsky (Eds.) Proceedings of the 13th ACM Conference on Recommender Systems. Copenhagen, Denmark. ACM. Pages 506-510.

[6] Pardos, Z.A., Jiang, W. (2020) Designing for Serendipity in a University Course Recommendation System. In K. Verbert, M. Scheffel, N. Pinkwart, & V. Kovanovic (Eds.) Proceedings of the 10th International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK). ACM. Pages 350-359.
